entry.title: U.S. Wants to See Russia Weakened, Says Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin After Ukraine Visit
entry.content: Mr. Austin’s comments came after he and Secretary of State Antony Blinken met with Ukraine’s president and announced more U.S. military aid to the country. In neighboring Russia, large fires broke out at fuel-storage facilities, while Moscow attacked Ukrainian railway hubs.

entry.title: Even in Defeat, Marine Le Pen Leads France's Far Right Closer to Power
entry.content: The candidate won 41.5% of the vote, showing that her once-fringe party is a political contender.

entry.title: Scale of Refugees From Ukraine War on Display in Poland's Public Schools
entry.content: Around 200,000 children have enrolled in schools since Russia invaded Ukraine. An estimated half-million are living in Poland and not yet enrolled.

entry.title: Russian Military's Next Front Line: Replacing Battlefield Equipment Destroyed in Ukraine
entry.content: Moscow’s heavy use and loss of weapons in Ukraine, combined with severe Western sanctions, will crimp its military might and lucrative arms exports for years, hindering its ability to produce everything from new weapons systems to spare parts.

entry.title: U.S. Withholds Sanctions on a Very Close Putin Associate: His Reputed Girlfriend
entry.content: Officials have a sanctions package ready, but they continue to weigh the potential backlash for blacklisting the 39-year-old former Olympic gymnast. The U.S. government says she is the mother of at least three of President Vladimir Putin’s children.
